title: Is it okay to reverse engineer a game?
content: I’m in game development, and recently got intrigued by reverse engineering. I would really like to reverse engineer a game and learn something from it, but that’s definitely illegal. How can I learn it then? Thanks!!

comments.text: Welcome to SE.EE! Please take the tour to learn how this site works, and read "How to Ask" and other pages of the help center. -- What specifically do you want to learn, the process of reverse engineering, or the inner working of that game? Your question is not quite clear, please edit it to clarify.

Hi and welcome to RE.SE. I suggest you look at existing Q&As with the law tag or search for Q&As with "legal" as search term on this site. To answer the question one would have to take your jurisdiction into account as well as the (original) jurisdiction of the copyright owners for the game etc. You can probably always do anything in private. But once you intend to publish your findings you should consult a lawyer. Probably few if any community members are lawyers. And even if they are, jurisdiction may differ and they're unlikely to render legal advice gratis.
I’d start by asking on gamedev.stackexchange.com how people think it was done. Someone will probably know, or be able to figure it out, and it’ll save you a huge amount of effort.
